snippet.textDisplay:
I got really confused at 14:25 when the young royalist explains that if the 
country's falling it's because everything's bound to connections with the 
power in place.

Is it just me or there is a very strong contrast between what he speaks 
about and what he represents? I can't believe it, it doesn't make sense at 
all. I guess what explains this discrepancy is the traditionalist/cultural 
perspective of power in Thailand. I think Vice has done a bad job on this 
one since we have no idea what the reforms those royalists speak about are 
all about, and yes I am aware they ousted the prime minister; I don't 
forget that.
 
I am completely neutral, I come from a democratic country but honestly I 
care to fully understand what this is all about beyond what pictures show.﻿

I'll try my best to explain and expand on what he said. Please, correct me 
if I am wrong. 

       I believe what he meant to say is that the custom of connections in 
the Thai society is the cause of its downfall and that he is merely playing 
by those rules, which are heavily influenced by the culture and traditions 
of the country, just like everybody else.  

        He argued that the custom itself, rather than Thaksin or a person 
such as himself, is the root cause of the problem in the society. It is 
fair to assume that these people and many like them have been coming and 
going in and out of the system for centuries. Nothing is going to change by 
removing Thaksin or Yingluck since there will be another one to replace 
them if the system itself does not change. This is the reason why the 
PDRC’s goal is to create a reform rather than engaging in another election. 
But I believe that the system’s reform with respect to the custom of 
connections is highly unlikely. Since all the systems in Thailand whether 
it may be social, political, or commercial are heavily influenced by 
connection and its associated power. Furthermore, every Thai person from 
all walks of life values connection and use it to a certain degree. So in 
order to change the system one would have to change the Thai’s culture and 
identity. 
       
        General examples of the influence of connection in the Thai 
systems. Some people only associate with their own class or higher for that 
the society, to a certain degree and scope, will look down on them if they 
choose to have a close connection with those from the class below them. 
Thus, weakening the connections that they have previously obtained. 
Additionally, it is ‘necessary’ for one to have the right and powerful 
connections if he/she would like to move up to a higher position in the 
political system. Since the more powerful person will most likely to 
promote only those that will act in a favorable manner to him/her and not 
because of their outstanding level of performance. 

       On a different note, with regards to the connections. A lot of 
benefits can be obtained from them in the Thai society, as the young 
royalist mentioned, including but not limited to financial (getting 
discounts), social (connections creating), and convenience (special parking 
spots). The better and the more powerful the connections you have, the 
better the benefits are going to be; more discounts, better parking spots, 
etc. In addition to the social pressure, this is the reason why the Thai 
people want to associate themselves to or be in the upper class. Moreover, 
this is why the ruling/upper class tends associate with each other in a 
tightly knitted community and create mutual benefits for each other.

       Finally, in relation to the red shirt movement. In Thailand it is 
especially hard for the vast majority of the population which are poor to 
move upward in the income bracket. Because of constraints such as the 
custom of connections, inequality of wealth distribution, education, 
financial situations, and many other factors. So they poor felt that they 
are being taken advantage of and is frustrated with the minimal opportunity 
given to them by the system. I believe that this is one of the main reason 
why they fought so hard for the ex-Prime Minister (Thaksin) who “promised” 
them wealth, prosperity, and opportunity. 

I hope this helps :)

+Chris Templet I think this is a common thread across all cultures. Just 
look at the videos from Kiev. Everyone can agree that the establishment is 
corrupt, but no one can agree on how to go about fixing it.

+Damien Marwood
The Ferrari scene is also very weird. I am asking you who is putting the 
other one in difficulty to your eyes in that scene? He seems to be 
perfectly aware of his country's situation and what the word "guts" really 
mean. He seems to be very aware that he is stuck between an angry mob, 
grenade launchers and a professional killer and yet he makes comment in the 
Ferrari about having guts to chose a non-conformist color. Now let me ask 
you, which party is the non-conformist one in this story?

I find the cigar's smoker guy to be quite an intriguing case really. The 
Yin and the Yang are fighting inside him I guess.

One reform that has been discussed is people outside of Bangkok not being 
allowed to vote, with the justification being that blacks and women used to 
be banned from voting in America when it was evolving therefore a similar 
system should be in place in Thailand while it is evolving. Ridiculous.

The reason Vice haven't illuminated what the reforms are all about is 
because they're are no concrete reforms, the leaders of the PDRC are just 
power-hungry 'democrats' who don't want to go to an election because they 
lose every time. So they made up a vague 'reform' agenda that has no 
substance to justify replacing a democratically elected government with a 
council of 'good people'

You can't blame Vice for not getting concrete reform ideas - they don't 
have it. Talked to many of the protesters - all tell you there have to be 
reforms before having new elections, because otherwise the "wrong" party 
would win again. But if you ask what the exact reforms plans are you don't 
get any answer. (Well some answered the election system should only allow 
people with a certain education degree, others suggested that one had to 
pay a certain amount of taxes to be valid to vote ... so to cancel the "one 
man one vote" rule - but I guess that were more personal ideas, not 
something the PDRC movement agreed on yet)

His comments emphasize his position in all of this. He is part of a small 
community of wealthy people and wants to keep it that way. They provide no 
arguments to support their cause....as they simply accuse the government of 
corruption without actually saying anything about how they're going to make 
things better. It's kind of sad really...

+Thor Jørgensen Not really, most monarchs that are overthrown are usually 
exiled.

Also, many monarchies in modern times have ruled without a democratic 
mandate and still have not been overthrown (e.g. the Middle East, where no 
monarchy has been overthrown by the Arab Spring).

+Thor Jørgensen I can see your point. I think especially the point that

that, there is an possibility that people might be satisfied with an 
non-democratic monarchy. Although I personally wouldn't agree with that any 
kind of monarchy. Just mentioning it again, to make very clear I'm not a 
supporter.

To all the incredibly ignorant people in the comments section who are 
insulting the King and the monarchy: kindly FUCK OFF.
What the hell do you outsiders know about Thailand, its history, and its 
politics? The fact is that the King is the only person holding Thailand 
together, and he has saved Thailand from destruction on multiple occasions. 
Without him and the institution he represents, Thailand would have been 
ripped apart by civil war like Vietnam, succumbed to genocide like 
Cambodia, or become an Orwellian military dictatorship like Myanmar. It's 
because of the strength of the monarchy that Thailand avoided being 
colonized like all of its neighbors. And it's the monarchy and the history 
which that monarchy represents that defines Thailand as a nation. Without 
the monarchy, there is no Thailand.
As to this particular issue, this is NOT a confrontation between royalists 
and non-royalists. The fact is that BOTH the Red Shirts and the Yellow 
Shirts are royalists who support the monarchy, as are 90 % of the Thai 
people. The only difference is that the Yellow Shirts lack a charismatic 
leader like Thaksin, and so they use the imagery of the King as a rallying 
figure for their movement, since he is the one person everyone loves and 
respects, and can unify behind.
Therefore, regardless of whether the Red Shirts or the Yellow Shirts win 
this confrontation, they and the Thai people will always remain loyal to 
the King and the monarchy as an institution. So before you ignorant 
outsiders start lecturing other countries, at least learn some basic 
history. This is an issue for the Thai people (and ONLY the Thai people) to 
decide for themselves. So you idiots can fuck off.﻿

Given, and the dichotomy here would seem to prove your point that whilst 
Government should provide cost affective impartial usage, it doesn't. It 
fosters more corruption and nepotism than would be tolerated from the 
private sector.

However:

It is in fact the private sector that corrupts true, impartial government. 
The idea that a utopian free market would emancipate the world from 
putrescence is a darling thought, but unregulated capitalism is simply a 
game of big-kill-small.
True Free-market economics is the fastest way to get owned by Rothschild. 
Watch a relatively small stock exchange like the SET and you'll clearly see 
how easily the hedge funds and banks collude in order to artificially 
inflate and short SET 100 shares. Collusion, insider-dealing etc may be 
illegal, but try and prove it – not so easy. In a true free-market global 
economy, who will police the activity?

On a differing note, I would also point out that business works for profit. 
If there is no profit in for example, finding a cure for a disease that 
only affects maybe a 1,000 people a year, the private sector will simply 
not pursue it. Profit relegates people to mere margin. If there is no 
apparent profit immediately foreseeable, no private organisation is going 
to pursue any venture simply for the sake of humanitarian grace.

Whilst I like your idea, I believe that it is ultimately flawed if only 
through the reasons cited above. That's not to suggest that democratised 
capitalism works either – how can anyone accept $millions of campaign 
donations and then imply political impartiality? Horse shit! Further more, 
not too dissimilar to the paragraph above, a democratically elected 
representative is likely to have campaigned on a media-hyped set of 
controversies. Is a more serious, pressing requirement going to be 
processed with appropriate priority, or will the representative pander to 
the media in the hope of winning his or her next term?

Communism is a nice idea, but has never really been tried – it can't work 
from the outset. “Everyone is equal except we, who are more equal”. In 
reality, every communist regime has in fact been a dictatorship or 
oligarchy. If everyone is equal, who's in charge?

Absolute monarchy and dictatorship amount to pretty much the same thing: if 
you get a really great guy it just might work, but chances are you just 
found Hitler, Mussolini, Henry VIII etc.

To my mind, the question of who is electable inevitably fails in its own 
search. Ask the question: “Do you want to run the country and have power 
over millions of lives?” If someone answers “Yes”, the chances are they are 
unfit to govern.
The ancients came pretty close to answering this quandary through one 
specific device: election of certain officials through means of lottery. 
Just like modern jury service, eligible (capable) candidates would be 
nominated for a fixed term without the possibility of  re-election. One 
shudders to imagine what criteria would be required to create a short-list 
of eligible candidates...

It's not just royalists that are corrupt and in power. There are just as 
many people that occupy high ranking positions in the private sector(these 
people mostly support the Pua Thai political party) that are corrupt and 
use the power that having money gives them in the wrong way. It's not just 
one side that is corrupt, both sides are. Each and everyone of these people 
that go on the street and "fight" for the political faction that they put 
their faith in is a puppet that is being played by a puppet master. I have 
experienced first hand how truly blind and brainwashed these people are. 
The working class southern conservatives think their king wants them to 
fight and oppress while the working class northern liberal red shirts want 
equality, freedom and liberty and are willing to step on the institutes of 
old like the crown and the families surrounding it. But the sad truth is 
that the people that lead these immense crowds, like Suthep Suban or 
Yingluck Shinawat don't share the same goals at all. They have their own 
goals in mind that don't concern what the little man wants, not one bit. If 
you truly believe that there is one faction that is better than the other 
for the whole of Thailands society, you have been played. Because the fact 
is that these factions don't give a crap about all their little followers. 
They might use them, tell the people what they want to hear and give them 
something to hope for, but that doesn't change the fact that they don't 
give a crap. I am Thai on my mothers side and have been living here for 
quite some time. Outsiders cannot possibly try to understand the current 
situation or who is doing the right thing if you haven't lived here and 
haven't experienced the reality of the upper and middle class in Thailand 
and most importantly what is going on behind the curtains. This is not 
America, or any first world western country for that sake where you can 
just say democracy is the right thing to do no matter what, it's not that 
simple. Corruption and aristocracy are a part of Thai society, society here 
need these things. You cannot just snip your finger, shout "long live the 
working class" and expect it to work in a country that may have been a 
democracy by name since the times of Rama the fourth but really, never has 
been a democracy in the first place. When corruption is so abundant and 
openly done by EVERYONE that it has almost integrated itself in the 
infrastructure of the country itself, it cannot be undone by simply 
replacing a couple of high end conservative pawns with a couple of liberal 
pawns, or the other way around for that matter. And if you really think 
that one faction is less corrupt than the next you're just plain stupid. 
There is a reason that Thaksin, the man himself, was at one point worth 
more than 2.3 billion dollars. He does not care any more about the "poor 
people" than the leaders of the opposition. His sister seems ok though, 
less content on cleaning up the old institutes and more focused on even 
more than her brother improving things for society as a whole. Although I 
do not like that practically all of north-west Thailand have been fooled 
into thinking there is a new age of prosperity waiting for them with the 
currently reigning government. There cannot be prosperity when there are 
just about zero natural resources apart from rice.﻿

Thais, me included, are mostly corrupt. When we get a traffic violation we 
will attempt to deal with the cop right then and there. Very politely: 
"Brother, Sir please help me out. I don't have time to go to the station. I 
will really appreciate the favor <sad-eyes>" Cop sticks his hand in the 
car, makes an extra THB 100 and seconds later we're on our way. Otherwise 
he takes the license and you have to go pay at the really out-of-the-way 
police station up to THB 800. Need to get our kids into a school? Better 
have the "Pae-Jia" or "5 - 6 figure donations" to the school in a crisp 
envelope, more if you kid's not top 25% (this starts at kindergarten.) Want 
to build a decadent resort in the national forest? Find the nearest Park 
Ranger and work your way up. Need something difficult done smoothly then 
grease the palm. I don't think the presence of (for a lack of a better 
word) daily-corruption that irks people so much as the intensity of 
systematic large scale corruption from the movers, shakers and government. 

Here's another uniquely Thai incident for thought. Motorcycles are not 
allowed on some overpasses. Instead of a cop being placed at the entrance 
to the overpass so as to stop motorbikes he is placed at the exit where he 
can then rush into traffic and stop the bike to elicit a fine. The bikes 
going up see this and turn around AGAINST TRAFFIC and ride down again away 
from the cop. Welcome to Thailand!

deserve criticism. This video depicts this as the establishment vs. 
democracy with Thaksin serving as some democratic idol. Thaksin is as 
corrupt as it gets. He has the support of the poor because he throws them 
scraps from his table while he quietly pillages the country and fattens his 
pockets. So a foreigner might look at this and say, he supports the poor, 
how bad could he be? Well, shouldn't he be creating a system where these 
people have a chance at leaving poverty for the middle class? As for the 
PDRC, while their argument that the uneducated impoverished masses don't 
know any better and will allow Thaksin to continue to bleed the country has 
merit, how can you justify killing the electoral process when your stated 
aim is reform?﻿

+Ngul Min Thang I do support equal opportunities for all Thai people too. 
There's no doubt that the poor people have been neglected for so long even 
when the party that claim to be helping them were in office. 

It is also true that the "rich elites" benefit from the traditional social 
structure of Thailand. And the fact that the elites from **both sides** 
heavily exploit the feudalistic social structure is probably of a different 
but related conversation.

The political problem that we are experiencing right now certainly came 
from the fact that the rural poor have been unfairly treated for so long. 
And in 2001, we elected a government that had the capability and mandate to 
affect real changes and they promised that they would help the poor as 
well. I myself had a real hope that they would do the right thing. But 
instead using the power to enrich themselves seemed to be their top 
priority. Despite the corruption, this government was still popular among 
the rural poor, which is totally understandable. After all, it's the 
closest thing that they had to a government that care about their well 
being and of course some of their policies were in fact effective in 
lifting the standard of living of rural and lower-income people.

So we are in a situation where a group of people want to prevent the 
cronyistic corrupt government from coming back, while another group want 
the government that helped the rural poor back in power. 

I believe that most people in Thailand will be happy with a democratically 
elected government that help the poor while putting the interests of the 
nation first. How such a government can be produced through a democratic 
framework is a conversation that I prefer to conduct rather than exchanging 
romanticized rhetoric.

+Omar Kreger-Alansari Funny that you bring up "the lesser of two 
evils"...that is what Thaksin's political career had reduced the Thai 
political system to! I voted him in 1998 (I think it was), and back then 
the Thai political landscape was as diverse as any! There were at least 10 
small, regional parties and a consilidation was overdue! Thailand had just 
gone through the 1997 economic crisis and both Banharn and Chavalit had 
been implicated in corruption scandals and financial irregulaties. Chuan 
Leekpai, an honest white blood democrat, had been entrusted with taking 
care of a transitionary government.

Enter Thaksin Shinawatra! Radical reforms, great ideas, big promises...just 
when the Thais needed it because of the bleak economic outlook...he had a 
simple philosophy - we'll spend our way out of it!! And amazingly, we 
did...it worked!! Investment started flowing back in, economy was back on 
its feet in no time! Thaksin was riding an all time high! 

It was then that his political agenda became clear...he literally bought 
out all the smaller parties - promising them posts in his new cabinet and 
goodies - and absorbed all these former mafioso prime ministers who had 
obviously passed their prime - chavalit, banharn, sanan, samak, chalerm, 
etc - into his very own Thai Rak Thai (Thais love Thai) party. Overnight it 
was a behemoth the likes of which had never been seen on Thai political 
landscape! His only true opponent in the 1998 elections, PM Chuan found 
himself in the minority in the parliament and resigned (at the election, 
thaksin had garnered 27% votes, Chuan 21%)

This is when the battle lines were drawn! The democrats had an image of a 
clean bureaucrat, lumpy and inefficient. The Thai Rak Thai were a rowdy, no 
nonsense corrupt bunch. Even if Thaksin HIMSELF wasn't corrupt (it is 
debatable), a confrontation was unavoidable! There was absolutely no 
opposition left...all the politicking had been set in stone! Whatever 
Thaksin wanted, Thaksin got and that isn't healthy for a democracy!!

The more I learn about Thailand the more I think the coup was the right 
decision.

your country as you will just ensure that the same corrupt 
political/banking/govt system endures for future generations. Most 
political parties in most countries are a sham as parties that bicker

oligarchies, with a select few that control a nation's military and 
monetary supply making all policy decisions, often imposing unpopular

under the guise of a "democracy". As long as a select few control the 
monetary supply of a nation, it is impossible for a functioning democracy 
to ever exist.﻿

+Sorawit Sta
I hear you, but I can't help but think you're missing the bigger picture 
here.

 80% of all government spending happens in BK, which holds only 18% of the 
population. This is a status quo that Thaugsuban wants to maintain, and 
will be easily accomplished so long as the Thai infrastructure outside of 
BK remains utterly crap.

400billion Bht seems a lot until you realise where it's going. Don't go 
thinking that farmers are getting fat, that money gets spent into the local 
and wider community, boosting all manner of businesses. Thailand has one of 
the most efficient agricultural system in the world; just as well, because 
outside of BK, that's pretty much all there is. Short of directly 
sponsoring large-scale industrialisation (which incidentally would require 
a proper transport network which keeps getting blocked by YKW), how else 
could you boost the Thai economy outside of BK? By targeting the farmers, 
the funding reaches every conceivable form of business further down the 
line.

Someone on these comments said “I don't want a bullet train to Chiang Mai” 
- why? Have you ever travelled BK-CM without catching a plane? It's pretty 
dire; you're talking 10 or more hours on a bus, & pretty much the same on a 
train for a distance that wouldn't take any longer than 2 ½ hours on a 
decent high speed rail network. In fact, travelling city to city anywhere 
in Thailand is a serious ball-ache. Come to think of it, after you've spent 
a couple of rather tedious hours waiting for your flight, it takes longer 
than 2 ½ hours even to fly BK-CM. Hmm, wonder who owns the airports & 
airlines...?

If a 21st Century network was installed, BK property prices would fall as 
people began to commute from areas where you can buy houses for a fraction 
of BK rates. The redistribution of wealth from these commuters would spawn 
new industry outside of BK. Anyone with half a brain would relocate to 
somewhere that isn't dropping into the ocean at the rate of 5cm per year. 
Who the hell would put a Billion Bht HQ in a city like this? It's sheer 
madness – only the political agenda makes Bangkok remotely viable from any 
perspective.

The sad truth is that if proper links were installed, all of the vested 
property & business interests that Thaugsuban & his cronies have in BK 
would become largely redundant. How do they avoid this? By relegating 
everywhere outside of BK to 3rd World status. THAT'S why they vetoed the 
train program. THAT'S why they will scream & rage at any initiative 
designed to help anyone outside of BK.

Frankly, I don't really care if Thaksin was a crook; most politicians are 
the world over. Why else would they become politicians in the first place? 
I would maintain that from an ethical standpoint, he was less crooked 
although probably more obvious than Thaugsuban and his fascist mob.

@Daniel Covington
Hi Dan,
You,  I'm sure know the saying,  "Behind every great fortune,  there's a 
great crime.",   but the problem is that whilst the term crime is a matter 
of perspective taken in its moral sense,  when you live in Thailand,  if 
you make money ethically,  the criminals in the government will think 
nothing of killing you to get it.  I'll give you an example,  I was 
reporting a billion dollar fraud which is being perpetrated by Balfour 
Beatty (Balfour Beatty plc,  UK based)'s British expat staff in Malaysia, 
 on the Double Track Project which goes from Kuala Lumpur to Bangkok,  so 
that they won't get the phases in Thailand when the Penang to Pedang Bessar 
section's signed off.

Despite the seriousness of the allegations they thought they'd play a 
hilarious joke of dropping me off in another station which turned out to be 
close when they left.  I went straight back,  and they had perked up and 
weren't all lying about sleeping.  They were busy,  but as I didn't want to 
be given the run around again I recorded them from outside.

They were busy extorting money out of an elderly man who'd had a car 
accident.  They are all doing this stuff everyday.  They are totally 
corrupt and can be bought no matter what's happened,  and worse,  will 
extort money out of crime victims,  and act as murderers for hire,  or at 
least they did during Tacsin's War on Drugs where they turned their hands 
to being in death squads with no real qualms.

In the town where my friend lives,  there's this building being built.  I 
presumed it was a temple as it's so big and grand.  The man who's getting 
it built is known to be a dangerous murderer.  He's a friendly enough guy, 
 but has a tendency to get his gun collection out for a spin when he's had 
a few too many whiskys.  It turns out this man used to be in the police, 
 so where's that money all come from.

Thais with Ferrari collections are a rarity,  granted,  but the whole 
effort to seek them out was part of the misdirection effort of Vice,  as 
there are millions of educated southerners who would be happy to give the 
interviewers chapter and verse on the reasons for the discontent---all of 
which the snidy journalist or his editors chose to present upside down and 
back to front.

Stealing all of the rice peasants' money from last year is off the wall 
stealing.  Thailand people aren't that educated,  but they're a lot more 
clued up than---say---British when it comes to being ripped off.  They pay 
no income tax and don't have mortgages,  so they are relatively free.  The 
effort is for George Soros' mates to starve them until they can buy that 
land up for really cheap.  Taksin is a Chinese subversive and his whole 
family ought to be tortured into giving over the money,  but they're being 
protected from somewhere,  which I guarantee is from outside of the 
country,  and I'm not talking about China.

that used elections to cover up its immense criminality. Thaksin Shinawatra 
who was in office from 2001-2006 mass murdered 3,000 people in just 90 
days. All of them were innocent - because none of them were formally 
charged, tried, or sentenced, just gunned down in the streets. He killed 
another 85 protesters the next year in a single day.  In his first term in 
office he disappeared or killed 18 human rights activists. In other words - 
he was a monster. 

He was finally ousted by a military coup because he would not give up power 
and was operating with absolute impunity (hence his ability to mass murder 
thousands and never see the inside of a jail cell). 

His successors were all openly his proxies - in other words, the man was a 
convicted criminal, a fugitive who fled the country, but was still running 
the ruling party through a series of nepotist proxies which included his 
brother-in-law and his own sister. Sound like democracy? Or a 3rd world 
banana republic?

machine, ending his impunity, and restoring rule of law (in other words, 
preventing him or someone else like him from procuring that much power and

An interesting take on the events from a leaked 2009 US cable:
Queen Sikrit, who unlike Bhumibol's keeping constitutional pretenses, is 
openly political and authoritarian, was for a long time champion of crown 
prince's VayjayLongCorn's succession but after the video of Foo Foo the 
dog's bizarre X-rated birthday party came out, she switched to the plan of 
being a regent to the young son of the crown prince's 3rd wife Srirasmi.

As Thaksin was widely perceived to be in cohorts with the prince, paid his 
gambling debts and such, when the succession dynamics changed, Thaksin had 
to go. Ultimately the high stakes game of the elites is all about 
succession, Thailand's moment of truth, as they call it, since various 
orbits of the network monarchy do not overlap and the coup is certainly a 
major boost for queen Sikrit since the top dogs in the junta are from the 
queen's guard faction, which means the power has been consolidated even 
further in the hands of Thailand's true No.1, the kingmaker, Privy Council 
Chair, the shadowy Prem Tinsulanond.

Sikrit, in an precedented 2008 move, abandoned any pretence of being above 
politics when she attended the funeral of a yellow shirt thug. US 
ambassador, in his cables, refrains from calling the yellow shirts fascists 
and refers to them as extreme right-wing ultra-royalists.

Another interesting thing in the cables is a statement that Thailand's 
strategic importance cannot be overstated. With a long history of overt and 
covert activities - the final episode of the Vietnam started from a US base 
in Thailand, the Koh Tang op against the Khmer Rouge and with land of the 
smile being not just a loyal ally in war on terror but giving up some of 
its sovereignty - key CIA black sites were in Thailand - it seems hard to 
predict how far US will actually go with sanctions.

accurate accounting of the situation in Thailand. I think you have very 
crudely misrepresented the goals of the PDRC, 'red' and 'yellow' shirt

insight into the place of royalty in the conflict.
